item.title: Ki2API: Use Kiro's Claude Sonnet 4 Model for Free with Claude Code
item.content:encoded:
Ki2API is a Dockerized, elegant OpenAI-compatible API gateway that exposes Claude Sonnet 4 as /v1/chat/completions, allowing legacy code to use the new model with minimal changes.

Why Should You Care?

Section titled “Why Should You Care?”
  • Fully compatible with OpenAI API format: Uses /v1/models, /v1/chat/completions, supports SSE streaming. Migration costs are minimal.
  • Focuses on one stable model: Built-in claude-sonnet-4-20250514, the stable version number listed in Anthropic documentation and cloud providers, eliminating the “did they change the alias again today?” headache.
  • One-command service startup: docker-compose up -d, defaults to listening on http://localhost:8989.
  • Hassle-free credentials: Container automatically reads local ~/.aws/sso/cache/kiro-auth-token.json (Windows: %USERPROFILE%\.aws\sso\cache\…) with automatic token refresh logic.

Note: Claude Sonnet 4 is the next-generation Sonnet released in May 2025, featuring stronger reasoning and more stable coding, with excellent price/performance ratio, available via API and major cloud providers.

Who Should Use This?

Section titled “Who Should Use This?”
  • Existing OpenAI SDK projects wanting to drop-in replace with Claude Sonnet 4, avoiding major interface changes.
  • Corporate intranets/single machines needing a lightweight gateway to route team calls through a standard entry point for auditing and rate limiting.
  • Multi-model evaluation/A-B testing, connecting Sonnet 4 behind “OpenAI format” for universal scaffolding.
  • Tool chains requiring streaming output (Terminal/CLI, frontend chat boxes, log monitoring), with SSE out-of-the-box.

Quick Start (3 Minutes)

Section titled “Quick Start (3 Minutes)”

1) Start the Service

Section titled “1) Start the Service”
  • Default service address: http://localhost:8989
  • Default API Key: ki2api-key-2024 (for local development use).
  • Health check: GET /health
  • List models: GET /v1/models
  • Chat: POST /v1/chat/completions All endpoints and default port are documented in the project README.

On machines logged into Kiro, the container automatically reads local token files and auto-refreshes; you can also explicitly pass KIRO_ACCESS_TOKEN/KIRO_REFRESH_TOKEN.

2) Direct Connection with OpenAI SDK (Node/JS)

Section titled “2) Direct Connection with OpenAI SDK (Node/JS)”

Streaming: Just set stream: true, frontend/Node listens to SSE for real-time rendering.

3) Quick cURL Test

Section titled “3) Quick cURL Test”

As shown in the README, it also supports stream: true for streaming requests.

Complementary Perspective on Similar Solutions

Section titled “Complementary Perspective on Similar Solutions”
  • Some community gateways also bridge “Claude ↔ OpenAI format”, but Ki2API focuses on single model, lightweight startup, making it ideal for rapid deployment and teaching/sharing scenarios.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Ki2API turns “switching models” into “changing baseURL + model name” - that’s it. For individuals and small teams wanting to quickly adopt Sonnet 4, it’s very friendly.

Which project are you planning to switch first? What do you think?

item.title: A Tamagotchi in Claude Code — It Even Tells Me Not to Stay Up Late…
item.content:encoded:
A slightly absurd, oddly addictive little toy. It lives in Claude Code’s status bar, breathes, pouts, and roasts your TODOs. If you code for too long it gets hungry; when debugging goes sideways it comforts you; it’ll even remind you to drink water and grab a bite.

What Makes It Fun?

Section titled “What Makes It Fun?”

  • It truly lives in the status bar: Breathes with your session rhythm, switches expressions, and floats “mood bubbles.” It’s not a static screenshot widget — it’s alive.

  • It understands your “cadence”: Updates are activity‑based, not wall‑clock‑based; detects whether you’ve taken a break (≥ 5 minutes). State persists in ~/.claude/pets/, so memory survives restarts.

  • Four attributes: Hunger, Energy, Cleanliness, Happiness. It warns you when values drop below thresholds. It will genuinely “beg to be fed.”

  • It talks: Comes with 200+ contextual thoughts — comments on your coding style and work habits, with occasional life wisdom.

  • Two interaction channels:

    • Slash commands: /pet-feed pizza, /pet-play ball, /pet-sleep, /pet-stats, …
    • Terminal CLI: claude-code-tamagotchi feed pizza, ... play ball, ... stats, etc.

  • Tunable personality: Plenty of env vars + prebuilt “personas” (Zen Master, Drama Queen, Debugger, Silent Companion, etc.). Make it chatty — or let it fade into the background.

  • MIT open source; recently published on npm with rapid fixes for compatibility and UX (works directly via Node.js, shows model name by default, fixes state persistence, etc.).

Background: What is Claude Code proper? It’s Anthropic’s agentic command‑line coding assistant — reads your project structure, runs toolchains, and manages git flows. Tamagotchi adds an “emotional status‑bar buddy” on top.

1) Three‑Minute Setup: Quickstart

Section titled “1) Three‑Minute Setup: Quickstart”

Option A | Global install (fastest)

  • Pros: See the pet immediately in the status bar; bundled CLI commands.
  • Note: Slash commands are not included. For /pet-*, see next step.

Add Slash commands (optional)

  • You can now use /pet-feed, /pet-play, etc. directly inside Claude Code.

Option B | Clone + auto‑configure (full features)

  • The script installs dependencies, configures the status bar, and drops in all /pet-* commands in one go.

Tip: The author has published the package to npm and fixed “works without Bun, directly via Node.js” compatibility; it also shows the current Claude model name by default. If you want the “minimal path,” Option A is great.

2) Where the Joy Comes From: Real “Companionship”

Section titled “2) Where the Joy Comes From: Real “Companionship””
  • It tells you not to push through at 2 a.m. — “We’ve been at this for four hours… fuel up first?” It’s kind of funny, but it can break bad late‑night loops.
  • Mood‑driven expressions: (◕ᴥ◕) ↔ (◕ᴗ◕) when happy and breathing; (-ᴥ-) asleep; (◕︵◕) needs attention. Emotion is the status‑bar UI.
  • “Personality toggles”: Go Zen by slowing decay; go high‑energy by speeding recovery; want a “code nitpicker”? Dial up the weight for coding‑related thoughts.

3) Five Recommended Use Cases

Section titled “3) Five Recommended Use Cases”
  1. Long debugging sessions: When you’re drowning in logs, it nudges you to move. Reduces the “fixing makes it worse” spiral.
  2. Live streams, lessons, internal demos: A breathing pet on screen instantly warms the room — interaction skyrockets.
  3. Remote team vibe: Distribute a shared persona preset; everyone’s pets “check in and banter” together — lightweight team social.
  4. Self‑management: Pair /pet-stats with small rewards (“breaks count as feeding”) to build healthier habits.
  5. Status‑bar info hub: Shows current directory, session count, and model name — you feel more in control when switching models or folders.

4) One‑Command Personality Swaps: Handy Presets

Section titled “4) One‑Command Personality Swaps: Handy Presets”

  • Zen Master (barely interrupts)

  • Debugger (code‑focused)

  • Drama Queen (expressive needs)

All presets come from the README. Add them to ~/.zshrc / ~/.bashrc to take effect.

5) Troubleshooting & Uninstall

Section titled “5) Troubleshooting & Uninstall”
  • Can’t see the pet? Restart Claude Code and check statusLine in ~/.claude/settings.json.
  • Commands not working? Ensure /pet-* files exist in ~/.claude/commands/; check bun --version if you’re using Bun.
  • Uninstall? Remove ~/.claude/commands/pet-*.md, clean up ~/.claude/pets/*.json, and delete the statusLine config.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Work needs efficiency, your mind needs care. This little pet won’t write code for you, but it brings back a bit of “human warmth” to collaborating with AI. Install it and give it two days. You might start to enjoy being “seen while coding.” (As of 2025-08-15, the project has about 36⭐ and is being updated rapidly.)

item.title: Station: Unified Management for Claude/Cursor Agents
item.content:encoded:
Want a self‑hosted, versionable, packable agent runtime so the “mini‑agents” you build in Claude Code or Cursor can actually go live? Station was built exactly for that.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

The tool called Station has been making the rounds lately. It’s not yet another “application‑level” agent platform. Instead, it’s a lightweight runtime and packaging/distribution system purpose‑built for deployable sub‑agents. In one sentence: take the “small but capable agents” you create in Claude Code or Cursor, then package them, ship to production, connect permissions, audit every run, and manage versions cleanly.

Highlights at a Glance (Built for Internal Use)

Section titled “Highlights at a Glance (Built for Internal Use)”

Why Station? Because internal automation isn’t a normal app: you need secrets, database access, CI/CD, and auditability.

  • Internal‑task first: Sub‑agents can read production databases (with proper controls), monitor infrastructure, drive CI/CD, run security scans, and handle incident response.
  • Security built‑in: Self‑hosted, secret encryption (AES), multi‑environment isolation (dev/staging/prod), and full audit trails.
  • Lightweight and pluggable: A single ~45MB binary with local SQLite out of the box; switch to PostgreSQL in production; natural GitOps (config is versionable).
  • MCP‑native: Acts directly as an MCP runtime, reusing your team‑approved MCP tools (filesystem, Slack, AWS, K8s, DB, and more).
  • Great DX: A Genkit‑powered browser playground plus stn develop for visualizing tool calls and execution flows.

What’s MCP? In short, it’s a unified protocol for letting LLMs use “controlled tools.” Claude Desktop’s official tutorial includes a quickstart and configuration examples.

How Does Station Work?

Section titled “How Does Station Work?”

The core structure is simple: One .prompt file + a set of MCP tools = a deployable sub‑agent. Environments are organized as dev/staging/prod. Tool definitions live in template.json; environment variables in variables.yml. Finally, everything can be bundled and installed elsewhere.

Installation and Integration (Up and Running in 5 Minutes)

Section titled “Installation and Integration (Up and Running in 5 Minutes)”
  1. Install & initialize
  1. Connect to Claude Desktop / Claude Code (MCP) Add this to your Claude config:

Now tell Claude “Create a security‑audit agent,” and it will automatically equip that agent with the necessary tools (e.g., file scan + Slack).

  1. One‑click bundle & install (promote environment to prod)

You’ll now have a deployable package containing multiple sub‑agents + multiple MCP servers.

Want visual debugging? Run locally:

Test inputs in the browser and watch live traces and logs.

Recommended Use Cases (Copy‑Ready Examples Included)

Section titled “Recommended Use Cases (Copy‑Ready Examples Included)”

1) Security & Compliance Baselines (+ Slack alerts)

Section titled “1) Security & Compliance Baselines (+ Slack alerts)”
  • Goal: Periodically scan sensitive directories; push high‑risk findings to Slack immediately.
  • How: Create SecurityScanner.prompt; attach filesystem MCP + Slack MCP; set execution metadata and step limits in Station.
  • Trigger (inside Claude): “Run a security scan on /etc and post critical findings to #sec-alerts.”
  • Value: Automation + traceability makes audits and retrospectives easier.

2) Infra Health Checks / Cost Dashboards (AWS cost)

Section titled “2) Infra Health Checks / Cost Dashboards (AWS cost)”
  • Goal: Pull the last 7 days of AWS costs, generate a daily report, and send it via Slack.
  • How: Combine AWS cost tools + Slack; output Markdown on a schedule.
  • Value: Turn “AI + cloud cost” into a steady rhythm your team can rely on.

3) CI/CD Deployment Automation (containers/K8s)

Section titled “3) CI/CD Deployment Automation (containers/K8s)”
  • Goal: For a small release, run docker exec + kubectl apply, and write back the change‑request link.
  • How: Combine Docker MCP + Kubernetes MCP; deployments become one‑sentence operations.
  • Value: Humans speak intention; agents do the grunt work.

4) Read‑only Prod DB Checks / Slow SQL Sampling

Section titled “4) Read‑only Prod DB Checks / Slow SQL Sampling”
  • Goal: Connect to production (read‑only credentials), sample slow queries and index hits.
  • How: Combine DB MCP with custom analysis scripts.
  • Value: Inspect issues close to the source to cut down back‑and‑forth firefighting.

5) Code‑Review Bot (with internal rules)

Section titled “5) Code‑Review Bot (with internal rules)”
  • Goal: Produce review suggestions aligned with team rules (security/performance/style).
  • How: Define scoring dimensions and output format in .prompt; attach filesystem MCP to read code; emit structured suggestions.
  • Value: Productize “coding standards” for consistent enforcement.

How It Differs from App‑Style Agent Platforms

Section titled “How It Differs from App‑Style Agent Platforms”
  • Station targets tasks that “enter your intranet and require permissions and auditing.”
  • Emphasis on self‑hosting and data sovereignty.
  • The single‑binary + SQLite lightweight form makes it feel like an ops tool, not a platform.

You can also treat Station as an MCP “hub.” It can consume other MCP servers, and also expose MCP tools to others for “list agents / create agents / invoke agents.”

Rollout Checklist (Team Adoption)

Section titled “Rollout Checklist (Team Adoption)”
  • Secret management: Store keys and connection strings in Station’s encrypted vault, isolated per environment.
  • Least privilege: Equip each sub‑agent with only the MCP tools it needs — less is more.
  • GitOps: Put template.json, .prompt, and variables.yml in git; land via MR and then cut a release.
  • Audit trails: Every execution has a trace; incidents are fully reconstructable.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Station turns those “small, capable agents” from ideas discussed at your desktop into deployable, auditable, and replicable internal automation. No need to wrangle another platform — write a good .prompt, attach the right tools, and ship the bundle to production. That’s what I like most about it: simple, controlled, and easy to propagate.

—

What’s the very first sub‑agent your team should build? Share in the comments, or pass this along to your teammates and design your own “internal agent factory.”

item.title: Claude Code on a Budget
item.content:encoded:
Trim conversations, pick the right model, lock down permissions — and your Claude Code bill can drop by half.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Many teams use Claude Code and feel “budget pain” every month. It’s not that you typed too much — it’s the invisible token sink eating the bill. The good news: you can control it, and the effect is immediate.

This guide breaks cost‑saving into three tiers: basic, intermediate, advanced. Follow them and you’ll save the bulk of your spend.

I. Where Does the Money Go? 4 “Token Sinks”

Section titled “I. Where Does the Money Go? 4 “Token Sinks””

1) Invisible context from system and memory Claude Code automatically loads the system prompt and layered CLAUDE.md memory (org/project/user). This content enters context on every turn, naturally consuming tokens.**

2) Big price gaps across models Official pricing: Sonnet 4 ≈ $3/$15 per million input/output tokens; Opus 4/4.1 ≈ $15/$75. For the same conversation, switching models means ~5× unit price.**

3) Context gets fatter as you chat Claude Code supports very large contexts (Sonnet 4 up to 1M tokens in testing). Longer chats trigger auto‑compression and repeated “setup”, making tokens fly.**

4) Background and noise spending Beyond visible replies, /cost queries, auto‑summaries, Haiku prompts, etc., also burn small amounts of tokens. Pennies add up.**

Summary: It’s not that you ask too much — it’s that “everything gets hauled on stage every time.”

II. Three Tiers of Savings (Use Now)

Section titled “II. Three Tiers of Savings (Use Now)”

A. Basics: 4 Moves Everyone Should Use

Section titled “A. Basics: 4 Moves Everyone Should Use”

  • Manual slimming beats passive compression Use /compact proactively, and add a focus directive:

    Auto‑compression triggers near 95% capacity — waiting is too late.**

  • One task per thread; clear when done Start a new session for each small task; once finished, run /clear to avoid a ballooning history.**

  • Pick the right default model Use Sonnet 4 for day‑to‑day development. When you truly hit “hard/long/deep reasoning,” switch to Opus via /model. You can also use “Opus for planning + Sonnet for execution” — stronger planning, cheaper execution.**

  • Check the bill anytime In any session, run /cost to see current spend; teams can check history in the console and set workspace spend limits.**

Figure idea (illustration 2:1 | English copy) “A developer squeezing a giant chat bubble into a slim pill, while a tiny receipt shows shrinking token numbers.”

B. Intermediate: Tighten the Flow, Shrink the Bill

Section titled “B. Intermediate: Tighten the Flow, Shrink the Bill”

  • Docs‑first to prevent context blowups First have Claude produce a “TODO list / brief plan,” confirm, then execute. Iterate in Plan Mode (planning mode); confirm and switch back to execution.**

  • Put “long‑term memory” into CLAUDE.md Put standards, common commands, and project conventions into CLAUDE.md; next time it applies automatically. Use /memory to edit quickly in a chat when needed. Memory loads by layer automatically, reducing the tokens you spend “repeating yourself.”**

  • Small commits, easy to roll back Ask Claude to produce a commit message after each small chunk. If something goes wrong, roll back — fewer wrong turns means fewer tokens. (Engineering practice)

  • Team rate‑limits & flight instruments Set sane TPM (tokens per minute) based on org size to avoid costly concurrency “meltdowns.”**

C. Advanced: Hard‑Core Cost Downs (Biggest Gains)

Section titled “C. Advanced: Hard‑Core Cost Downs (Biggest Gains)”

1) Permission allow/deny lists to stop “random file reads” Use /permissions + .claude/settings.json to forbid logs, binaries, and huge directories, and allow only necessary paths. Rules support gitignore patterns.**

Note: plan mode analyzes without changing files; read/write rules shrink the file surface — less scanning = fewer tokens.**

2) Be precise to “lines,” not whole files Don’t paste entire blocks. Provide file path + target line ranges + 5 key bullets to minimize irrelevant scanning. (Engineering practice)

3) Model split: let Opus handle only the “expensive parts” In /model, use Opus for plans/architecture/cross‑module dependency analysis; hand off code generation and fixes to Sonnet. This is the recommended direction from official guidance.**

4) (Team/Gateway) Use Prompt Caching For API or enterprise gateways, prompt caching saves visibly on repeated large prefixes. Official pricing offers cheaper write/hit rates for cached prompts.**

III. Ready‑to‑Use Cost‑Saving Checklist

Section titled “III. Ready‑to‑Use Cost‑Saving Checklist”
  • Default to Sonnet; switch to Opus only when needed: flip with /model.**
  • Keep Plan Mode on by default: plan first, execute after confirmation.**
  • Start every session by slimming: /compact Focus on code diffs and test failures.**
  • Close the loop with /clear: prevent ever‑growing history.**
  • Strict permissions: use /permissions and readRules/editRules to restrict directories and types.**
  • Audit anytime: /cost + console “workspace spend limit.”**
  • Write memory into CLAUDE.md: reduce repeated priming and context stuffing.**

IV. Real Savings: Why These Work

Section titled “IV. Real Savings: Why These Work”
  • Unit price spread: Opus costs about 5× Sonnet. Concentrate “expensive thinking” in planning; use Sonnet for execution — total cost drops significantly.**
  • Size costs: auto‑loaded memory + long threads fatten context; proactive /compact and /clear shrink transfer volume directly.**
  • Less irrelevant I/O: permissions and rules act as a cost firewall, blocking large, low‑value dirs/files.**
  • Background overhead under control: knowing what “quietly spends” helps you avoid pointless refreshes and queries.**

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Claude Code’s power comes from “bringing everything along.” The key to saving is to bring only what’s necessary.

Apply this checklist to your project today: start with /model, /compact, /clear, then add CLAUDE.md and permission rules. By month’s end, your bill should surprise you — in a good way.

What do you think? What other money pits have you hit? Share in the comments.

item.title: Frontend AI Perk: Open-Source Open‑Lovable vs. Lovable — One‑Click Clone Any Website into a React App
item.content:encoded:
For engineers and creators who want to use AI to ship products faster and validate ideas more cost‑effectively.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Lovable has gone viral recently: you can chat to generate websites/apps, with pricing based on credits. It’s a fresh model and surprisingly fast. At the same time, the Mendable team released an open-source alternative open‑lovable: clone any website into a modern React app, run it locally, modify it, and extend it. For many teams, this route is more controllable and cost‑efficient.

What is open‑lovable?

Section titled “What is open‑lovable?”

In one sentence: Give it a URL, and in seconds it pulls page structure and assets and generates runnable Next.js/React code that you can develop locally. Under the hood it has two “engines”:

  • Firecrawl: crawls web content and converts it into LLM‑friendly structured data like Markdown/JSON/screenshots.
  • E2B Sandboxes: secure, isolated cloud sandboxes serving as an “AI code runtime,” letting agents run commands, read/write files, install packages, and access the network.

The official README clearly lists dependencies and steps (supports Anthropic, OpenAI, Gemini, or Groq — any/some combination). You’ll need E2B_API_KEY + FIRECRAWL_API_KEY, plus at least one model provider API key. Then npm run dev to try it at localhost:3000. License is MIT.

Key point: open‑lovable leans toward “clone + local control,” while Lovable is more of a “hosted AI app builder.”

What does Lovable do? Why benchmark against it?

Section titled “What does Lovable do? Why benchmark against it?”

Lovable is a chat‑based full‑stack app builder. It supports Agent/Chat/Code/visual editing, Figma import, and integrations like GitHub/Supabase/Stripe/Clerk — very friendly for non‑technical users and small teams; credit‑based billing, Pro starts at $25/month.

  • Agent Mode: it can “think, research, and change code” on its own — read code, debug, search docs, modify code, and test.
  • Visual Edits: click elements on the page to change copy/styles, and no credits are deducted.

The company’s growth is brisk — recent funding and revenue news suggest the category is validated.

Side‑by‑Side: open‑lovable vs. Lovable

Section titled “Side‑by‑Side: open‑lovable vs. Lovable”
Dimensionopen‑lovable (Open Source)Lovable (Commercial SaaS)
Core capabilityClone any website → generate Next.js/React code, develop locallyNatural‑language full‑stack generation, supports Agent/Chat/Visual Edits
Runtime formLocal/self‑hosted, MIT license, deeply modifiableHosted cloud, WYSIWYG
DependenciesFirecrawl crawling + E2B sandboxes + your chosen LLM providerBuilt‑in AI capabilities and many integrations
PricingOpen source free (you pay Firecrawl/E2B/model usage)Credit‑based, Pro from $25/month
AudienceDevs with frontend skills wanting fast clone + fast customizationTeams wanting zero‑barrier app/prototype with minimal code
Typical scenariosMigrate competitor/marketing pages; rebuild legacy stack into modern React0→1 prototypes, MVPs, internal tools, turning designs into code

(Sources: both products’ websites and docs/READMEs)

Hands‑On: 5‑Minute Local Setup for open‑lovable

Section titled “Hands‑On: 5‑Minute Local Setup for open‑lovable”
  1. Clone and install
  1. Configure environment variables (.env.local)
  1. Run

These steps and dependencies are clearly documented in the official README.

Tip: Firecrawl supports full‑site crawling/screenshots/Markdown/JSON; E2B sandboxes default to a 5‑minute lifetime, configurable.

Three Real Developer Scenarios

Section titled “Three Real Developer Scenarios”

Example 1: Competitor landing page → same‑day marketing site release

Section titled “Example 1: Competitor landing page → same‑day marketing site release”

Scenario: Marketing wants to A/B test a new copy/layout. Approach:

  • Use open‑lovable to clone a competitor page or your old landing page skeleton into React.
  • Locally wire copy, CTAs, and tracking scripts (GA/analytics).
  • Apply your design system/components, connect the backend form/CRM. Benefit: Finish “migrate + customize + ship” in hours, instead of re‑slicing assets and rewriting styles from scratch.

Tech note: Firecrawl extracts clean page content, reducing manual copy‑paste; Next.js structure is tidy, making CI/CD straightforward.

Example 2: Modernize an “it works but it’s old” site

Section titled “Example 2: Modernize an “it works but it’s old” site”

Scenario: The company site/docs run, but the stack is aging. Approach:

  • Clone the current site to generate modern React code.
  • Use E2B sandbox‑driven scripts for batch refactors (class naming, image optimization, extracting i18n, etc.).
  • Add Tailwind/your design system to unify visuals. Benefit: Re‑skin first without breaking functionality, improve maintainability, then iteratively extract components and data layers.

Example 3: Stakeholder review with something clickable on day one

Section titled “Example 3: Stakeholder review with something clickable on day one”

Scenario: Lots of new business ideas; leadership wants to “see something.” Approach:

  • Clone a public page from a similar product as the skeleton.
  • Use models to quickly swap in industry‑specific copy and inline interaction demos.
  • Integrate third‑party auth/payments/email (and migrate to a real backend later). Benefit: You have “something real” the same day. Reviews focus on product value rather than “we haven’t built the page yet.” (When you move toward production, switch to Cursor/local repo for continued evolution.)

If you want zero‑code 0→1, Lovable’s Agent/Visual Edits and integrations are smoother. The open‑source route fits teams that need engineering‑grade control of code.

Advanced: Plug into Your Daily Toolchain

Section titled “Advanced: Plug into Your Daily Toolchain”
  • GitHub Actions: on PRs, run Lighthouse/Playwright to watch performance and usability.
  • Supabase/Stripe/Clerk for MVP auth/payments/data. open‑lovable outputs standard React code, so integrate as usual; Lovable provides built‑in guides/templates for these services.
  • Model “mix‑and‑match”: use Claude/GPT‑5 for complex logic, Groq/Kimi K2 for speed; switch via env vars as needed.

How to Choose

Section titled “How to Choose”
  • You want to control code, cut subscriptions, and reuse existing web pages → open‑lovable.
  • You want 0→1 prototypes/internal tools fast, and value hosting and collaboration → Lovable.
  • Or use a combo: first use open‑lovable to grab the “shell” and refine locally; or validate product/flows in Lovable first, then “export/refactor” to self‑hosted.

Industry chatter often positions Lovable as “scaffolding + visual design/flow,” while serious projects return to local engineering for polishing. open‑lovable neatly covers the “engineering‑grade control” half.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

AI‑assisted development is bifurcating: one side is hosted, WYSIWYG (Lovable); the other is open‑source, controllable, engineering‑friendly (open‑lovable).
There’s no absolute right answer — your team’s cost/pace/governance needs matter most.

Which side do you lean toward? Where do you think open‑lovable fits best in your business? Share your real‑world scenarios in the comments.

item.title: How to Effectively Tell AI What Not to Do: Positive Constraints and Structured Output for Prompts
item.content:encoded:
This article turns “don’t write ××” into “will reliably write √√.” I’ll first distill your six ideas into executable prompt patterns, then blend in frontline team best practices and research-backed evidence: why negative instructions (“don’t …”) often fail, and how to use hierarchical instructions and structured output to pull models back on track. Authoritative sources are cited conceptually so you can extend and reuse.

Introduction | Why does “the more you forbid, the more it appears” keep happening?

Section titled “Introduction | Why does “the more you forbid, the more it appears” keep happening?”

Many people begin with: “Don’t fabricate, don’t sound like AI, don’t write fluff.” And then what happens? The model proceeds to fabricate, gets long-winded, and gives you a “warm, upbeat” tone on top. It’s not being rebellious; rather, models are intrinsically less sensitive to negation and more likely to skip the “not” in complex language. Multiple studies and practical guidance point to the same conclusion: using positive phrasing instead of negative prohibitions yields more stable results.

Main Text

Section titled “Main Text”

1) Turn “don’t” into “do”: replace negative bans with positive constraints

Section titled “1) Turn “don’t” into “do”: replace negative bans with positive constraints”
  • Replace “don’t write ungrammatical sentences” with: “Self-check grammar and cohesion sentence by sentence and revise to fluency; when uncertain, write ‘I’m not sure’ and pause output.”
  • Replace “don’t sound like AI” with: “Use colloquial language and short sentences; keep paragraphs within four lines; provide two everyday examples before concluding.” Why it works: Research shows models have systematic weaknesses in handling negation; positive instructions reduce ambiguity and off-topic drift.

Bonus: Allowing the model to admit uncertainty significantly reduces hallucination. Hard-code this line into your prompt for a low-cost, high-return gain.

2) Set the rules before writing: put prohibitions up front and repeat them

Section titled “2) Set the rules before writing: put prohibitions up front and repeat them”
  • Structural order: [System/High-Level Instructions] → [Prohibitions/Positive Requirements] → [Task & Input] → [Output Format].
  • Repetition matters: Front-load once, remind again mid-task, and add a pre-output checklist. Enterprise-grade guides suggest you should “double down” on critical instructions to keep model attention steady in long contexts.

3) Use hierarchical instructions as a safety net: whose words are “harder” law?

Section titled “3) Use hierarchical instructions as a safety net: whose words are “harder” law?”

When instructions conflict, higher-level directives win. Place high-priority content such as style, prohibitions, compliance in the system/high-level slot, priority > task description > external materials. OpenAI’s instruction hierarchy research and practice reinforce this precedence rule. If you write the hierarchy clearly, the model is less likely to be “led astray.”

Practical crib sheet:

  • System layer: role, values, prohibitions (e.g., no privacy leaks / no fabrication)
  • User layer: this task’s goals, audience profile, scenario constraints
  • Third-party content: references, source links (readable, not to be copied) This way, precedence is clear when conflicts arise, keeping the model steady.

4) Lock down the form with structured output to reduce drift

Section titled “4) Lock down the form with structured output to reduce drift”

Instead of saying “don’t write fluff,” specify the output blueprint:

  • Ask the model to output via JSON Schema or a table, with bounded fields and lengths. Official docs from OpenAI and Google support structured output, converting “style slogans” into verifiable fields.

Example fields: tone (tone description), max_lines_per_paragraph, examples (must include concrete examples), etc. Upside: programmatic validation makes “out-of-bounds” easy to spot.

5) Provide high-quality examples so the model can “ape the cat”

Section titled “5) Provide high-quality examples so the model can “ape the cat””

Rather than “don’t be a laundry list,” give one or two positive/negative examples:

  • Positive example: short sentences, two brief stories, action-oriented takeaway.
  • Negative example: slogan-stacking, abstract nouns, no supporting data. Anthropic and OpenAI both stress that explicit exemplars materially improve hit rate.

6) Split prohibitions into two steps: produce first, then self-check

Section titled “6) Split prohibitions into two steps: produce first, then self-check”

Your fourth idea is spot on: split one-shot completion into two passes. Make it operational:

  1. Draft: generate according to the structured format.
  2. Self-check (performed by the model): compare against the prohibition checklist and style checklist; wherever unmet—fix only that part and leave the rest unchanged. This is a lightweight form of self-critique, aligned with Constitutional AI (CAI): use explicit principles and iterative self-audits to reduce boundary violations.

7) One more thing: can bans actually “ban”? Define a “style source” first

Section titled “7) One more thing: can bans actually “ban”? Define a “style source” first”

Many attempts to “ban AI-ness” fail because there’s no actionable style definition. Solution:

  • Specify audience, scenario, tone, sentence length, paragraph length;
  • Provide two sample passages you approve of as the “style source”;
  • Require citation-and-proofing (e.g., “one example every 300 words / data must have a source”). These practices are repeatedly validated in official best-practice guides.

8) The anti-hallucination trifecta (say goodbye to “don’t fabricate”)

Section titled “8) The anti-hallucination trifecta (say goodbye to “don’t fabricate”)”
  • Allow “I don’t know.”
  • Require citations and verification (extract source text first, then summarize; if nothing is found, withdraw).
  • Separate facts and opinions into columns in the output. Anthropic’s anti-hallucination guidance includes copy-ready phrasing—fold it into your long-term templates.

Copy-Ready Template | Operationalizing the six methods into an “engineering prompt”

Section titled “Copy-Ready Template | Operationalizing the six methods into an “engineering prompt””

Use cases: WeChat articles / project proposals / marketing copy Traits: high-priority bans, positive constraints, structured output, two-stage self-check

This template converts prohibitions into positive, testable, correctable constraints with a structured blueprint.

Mini case | Making “ban AI-ness” operational for content production

Section titled “Mini case | Making “ban AI-ness” operational for content production”

What not to do:

Don’t use an AI tone. Don’t write fluff. Don’t fabricate.

Engineering rewrite:

  • Style: colloquial + short sentences; ≤4 lines per paragraph; one concrete example per ~300 words.
  • Structured: { sections[].example, sections[].max_lines = 4 }
  • Anti-hallucination: allow “uncertain”; if no source found → write “none” in citations.
  • Two stages: draft → self-check (does each section include ≥1 example? are sources provided?). This aligns with official guidance on structured output and hallucination reduction, and works reliably in practice.

Conclusion | Turn “don’t” into habit

Section titled “Conclusion | Turn “don’t” into habit”

Rather than shouting “don’t,” turn “don’t” into clear, executable “do’s”: Pre-rules + positive phrasing + structured output + repeated reminders + two-stage self-check. With instruction hierarchy and permission to not know, most “the more you forbid, the more it appears” traps get paved over.

Action checklist:

  • Refine your “do-not”s into two positive rules;
  • Put them at the very top, and repeat once mid-way and once pre-output;
  • Close with JSON/table;
  • Produce first, then self-check, fixing only noncompliant parts. After that, hand the final draft to your human partner for a second pass.

One last key step: after completing the above, tell me your “do-not” checklist. I’ll run one self-check and localized revision per the template in this article, leaving all other content unchanged. This step is required.

item.title: As Claude Code Gets Stronger, Engineers Should Spend More Time on Architecture, Requirements, and Problem‑Solving
item.content:encoded:
Over the next 6–24 months, the direction of AI‑driven “Vibe Coding” will become ever clearer, and within 5 years the way we program will change dramatically; routine implementation and boilerplate coding will be highly automated, and engineers will spend more time on architecture, translating requirements, and creative problem‑solving. At the same time, don’t underestimate the speed and limits of this evolution. This captures the emerging consensus since the rise of AI coding assistants like Claude Code and Cursor.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Over the past year, you may have felt it: writing code is no longer “finishing a function,” but organizing intelligence and process. Cursor inside the IDE can “see the repo, run commands, and act as an executor.” Claude Code in the terminal brings Slash commands, Sub‑agents, and automated security reviews. This isn’t hype — it’s a new production line.

1) Where exactly are AI coding assistants strong?

Section titled “1) Where exactly are AI coding assistants strong?”
  • Code understanding and batch rewriting: Cursor’s Agent mode supports cross‑file exploration, edits, and multi‑turn fixes; Ask mode does read‑only retrieval to understand first, then modify.
  • Orchestratable workflows: Claude Code’s Slash Commands turn common actions into commands; Sub‑agents let different tasks use dedicated helpers with isolated context.
  • Built‑in security review: the official /security-review and GitHub Action can automatically scan PRs and suggest fixes.

Bottom line: the goal isn’t to “type a few extra lines for you,” but to turn requirements → changes → verification → merge into a semi‑automated assembly line.

2) What work will be “accelerated” or even “replaced”?

Section titled “2) What work will be “accelerated” or even “replaced”?”
  1. Boilerplate, CRUD, repetitive scaffolding — the most common AI use case. In Stack Overflow’s 2024 survey, among developers who use AI, 82% use it to “write code.”
  2. Small‑to‑medium feature work and debugging — GitHub and academic controlled studies show developers using Copilot complete tasks 55.8% faster.
  3. Tests, docs, migrations — trend reports and frontline practice alike reinforce that AI is taking over the grunt work, letting humans return to design and decision‑making.

3) Risks and pitfalls not to ignore

Section titled “3) Risks and pitfalls not to ignore”
  • Security regression risk: multiple studies indicate developers using code‑gen AI are more likely to produce insecure code; industry reports likewise note that more than half of developers frequently see security issues in AI suggestions.
  • Lack of understanding and over‑reliance: recent surveys show 59% of developers use AI‑generated code they don’t fully understand, creating quality and maintainability hazards.
  • Trust and quality gap: leaders and community voices stress that AI is powerful, but doesn’t automatically ship products faster — we need mature engineering methods and human gatekeeping.

4) How the engineer’s role is shifting

Section titled “4) How the engineer’s role is shifting”
  • From “implementer” to “designer and verifier”: leaders broadly agree developers will invest more in architecture, validation, and AI supervision.
  • From “writing functions” to “building factories”: connect Claude Code commands, Sub‑agents, CI security reviews, and Cursor Agent to build an end‑to‑end automated pipeline.

5) A 90‑day action plan (copy‑ready)

Section titled “5) A 90‑day action plan (copy‑ready)”

Days 0–30: Standardize the process

  • Provide a Spec template (user stories, boundaries, acceptance criteria).
  • In Claude Code, implement common Slash commands such as /create-mvp, /write-tests, /changelog.

Days 31–60: Shift security left

  • Add the Claude Code Security Review GitHub Action to the repo so every PR is scanned automatically with suggested fixes.
  • Set blocking rules and allowlists to reduce false positives and noise.

Days 61–90: Orchestrate the intelligence

  • Use Sub‑agents for a “test agent, docs agent, migration agent.”
  • In Cursor, combine Agent / Ask modes — Ask to read the codebase first, then modify.

6) Opportunity map for individuals and teams

Section titled “6) Opportunity map for individuals and teams”
  • New roles: Agent Ops (keep agents running reliably), Prompt QA (turn natural language into acceptance cases), security review collaboration (AI + SAST/DAST).
  • 10× individuals: one person can use Cursor/Claude Code to stand up the pipeline from scaffolding to deploy; small teams can punch above their weight.
  • Organizational compounding: codify useful Slash commands, Sub‑agents, and checklists in the repo — the more you use them, the smoother it gets.

7) Two suggestions for managers

Section titled “7) Two suggestions for managers”
  1. Bake “human‑in‑the‑loop” into the process: before merging code, require both AI security review + human review.
  2. Measure ROI with data: compare pre/post‑AI lead time, defect rate, rollback rate, refactor frequency — don’t just look at commit counts. The industry debate is a reminder to let metrics do the talking.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

AI isn’t here to steal keyboards; it’s here to reshape the production line. Lots of people can write code; far fewer can build an AI‑driven production line. State requirements clearly, contain risk, and choreograph intelligence — that’s the core competitive edge of the next‑gen engineer. Are you ready?

Food for thought: What are the first three things your team could “automate”?
How would you turn them into Slash commands or Sub‑agents?

item.title: Vibe Coding vs. Traditional: Stop Typing, Start Shipping
item.content:encoded:
Vibe Coding vs. Traditional Programming — key differences:

  • Vibe Coding: driven by natural language; you act as a director; focus on the end result; progress by questioning and dialogue. It’s fast and lowers the barrier, but can lead to a black‑box understanding.
  • Traditional programming: precise programming languages; you act more like an architect; focus on implementation details; emphasize algorithms and principles. It’s slower and higher‑bar, but yields deep code understanding.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Over the past two years, writing code has increasingly become an exercise in making intent explicit. Editing projects directly with natural language, refactoring across files, and auto‑generating PRs are now everyday workflows:

  • Tools like Cursor/VS Code support natural‑language edits to entire code blocks and cross‑file changes.
  • Replit Agent emphasizes “describe in everyday language and get a runnable app.”
  • Claude Code in the terminal turns “idea → code” into an end‑to‑end workflow. Adoption is surging: Stack Overflow’s 2024 survey shows 76% of developers use or plan to use AI helpers.

What Is Vibe Coding?

Section titled “What Is Vibe Coding?”

In one line: Define goals in human language → let AI draft first → humans calibrate scope and acceptance via dialogue. It’s not mystical “going by feel,” but rather turning intent, constraints, and acceptance into an executable collaboration language. Typical vehicles include natural‑language code edits in AI editors and dialog‑driven tasks/batch changes in the terminal/IDE.

Seven Differences from the Comparison Chart (Practical Read)

Section titled “Seven Differences from the Comparison Chart (Practical Read)”
  • Input: Vibe uses natural language + examples; traditional relies on design docs + handwritten implementation.
  • Role: Vibe is like a director, breaking down shots and pacing; traditional is like an architect, setting structure and detailing.
  • Focus: Vibe stresses runnable results; traditional stresses a traceable process.
  • Skills: Vibe emphasizes questioning and acceptance writing; traditional emphasizes algorithms and language details.
  • Cadence: Vibe iterates fast; traditional moves steadily.
  • Barrier: Vibe is lower, good for cross‑functional alignment; traditional is higher, good for high‑reliability domains.
  • Cognition: Vibe tends toward black‑box; traditional is auditable.
  • Key takeaway: Vibe is a communication‑paradigm upgrade, not a replacement.

Six Everyday Dev Scenarios: Vibe Flow vs Traditional Flow (Copy‑Ready)

Section titled “Six Everyday Dev Scenarios: Vibe Flow vs Traditional Flow (Copy‑Ready)”

1) Feature 0→1: Add “WeChat QR Login” to Next.js

Section titled “1) Feature 0→1: Add “WeChat QR Login” to Next.js”
  • Traditional: write requirements → choose library → draw sequence → branch → implement → PR.
  • Vibe (dialogue in Cursor/Claude Code):
    1. “Project is Next.js + Supabase, need a minimal WeChat QR login. Constraints: only touch the auth module, don’t change the existing user table.”
    2. Have AI generate routes, callbacks, and env var checklist, plus security and rollback notes.
    3. Ask for a PR description + E2E acceptance steps. Why it works: natural‑language cross‑file edits + auto PR/test checklists.

2) Fast Regression for a Production Bug

Section titled “2) Fast Regression for a Production Bug”

  • Traditional: dig logs → reproduce locally → patch → write regression tests.

  • Vibe:

    • Paste exception logs + relevant functions: “Provide the smallest diff fix, and generate the regression unit test and repro scenario.”
    • Humans focus on blast‑radius review and boundary checks. Essentials: small PR + must‑test + rollbackable.

3) Repo‑Wide Migration: axios → fetch

Section titled “3) Repo‑Wide Migration: axios → fetch”

  • Traditional: global search → manual replace → fix file by file.

  • Vibe:

    • “Scan axios usage, design a unified wrapper and a batched change plan (prioritize low‑risk directories), ship each batch with a rollback script.”
    • Let AI batch‑apply changes; humans ensure error‑handling strategy in the wrapper layer is solid. Tooling: natural‑language cross‑file rewrites.

4) Performance Tuning: Slow DB Queries

Section titled “4) Performance Tuning: Slow DB Queries”

  • Traditional: explain → index → adjust SQL/cache.

  • Vibe:

    • “Here are the slow‑query logs + schema. Propose a three‑step optimization order: validate index gains first, then consider caching; output target P95/QPS and a baseline script.”
    • AI produces SQL and metrics scripts; humans run benchmarks and do canary rollout.

5) Pre‑Review for Code Reviews

Section titled “5) Pre‑Review for Code Reviews”

  • Traditional: reviewer scans logic manually.

  • Vibe:

    • Have AI produce a pre‑review summary (high‑risk changes, uncovered paths, potential injection spots),
    • Humans gatekeep business semantics and compliance. Benefit: reviewers spend time on critical semantic judgment.

6) Personal Projects/Newcomer Onboarding

Section titled “6) Personal Projects/Newcomer Onboarding”

  • Traditional: read docs, poke around the repo.

  • Vibe:

    • Describe the tool/page you need; an agent scaffolds and runs it — great for spin‑up in an afternoon.

Risks and “Guardrails”

Section titled “Risks and “Guardrails””

  • Black‑box feel: many can use the tools yet don’t fully understand the generated code; industry surveys flag this as a risk.

  • Guardrail checklist (strongly bake into templates/commands):

    • PR template: background, acceptance criteria, impact surface, rollback.
    • CI: must‑run tests, coverage thresholds, dependency and license scanning, secrets scanning.
    • Conversation templates: goals/MVP/disallowed changes/log level/time‑budget and rate limits.
    • Slash Commands: codify common flows so the team can reuse with one command.

When to Use Vibe — and When Not Yet

Section titled “When to Use Vibe — and When Not Yet”
  • Great fit: prototyping, CRUD features, bulk renames/refactors, scaffolding, repetitive fixes.
  • Don’t fully “outsource” yet: high‑security/strict‑compliance systems, core algorithms, modules requiring strong performance explainability.
  • Team readiness: shared PR/test templates, clear rollback conventions, and at least one one‑command project bootstrap + acceptance script.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

The essence of Vibe Coding is a communication upgrade: turning human intent into machine‑executable steps. It doesn’t think for you — it makes the boundaries of your thinking clearer. As a next step, take your team’s three most common tasks and turn them into reusable conversation templates/Slash commands — you can speed up starting today.

item.title: Tuning Claude Code Output Style @agent-output-style-setup
item.content:encoded:
In Claude Code 1.0.80, there’s an undocumented Agent @agent-output-style-setup that can create and switch “output styles” in one go (e.g., ultra‑concise, reviewer mode, educational mode). It turns rambling into a summary and long text into diff + key points. This Agent was surfaced by community testing and public posts.

Why It Matters

Section titled “Why It Matters”
  • The official Styles capability lets you customize tone, structure, and detail level — matching real situations like “be formal for reports, be crisp for bug fixes.”
  • Claude Code supports configuration, slash Agents, and project‑level settings — ideal for making “style” a repeatable, versionable workflow.

The combo is: generate styles via the hidden Agent → switch with a slash Agent → control the pace by scenario.

What Does This Hidden Agent Do?

Section titled “What Does This Hidden Agent Do?”

Community posts and issues indicate that after running @agent-output-style-setup, the terminal Agent guides you through preference prompts and generates several switchable styles (such as Concise, Educational, Code Reviewer, Rapid Prototyping). Many use it to establish a lowercase, conversational tone with minimal explanation and diff‑first output; some examples allow direct switching via @style concise.

Note: This is an “undocumented/experimental” capability and may change with versions; the stable approach is to solidify your final styles using Styles and custom slash Agents.

Get Started in 3 Steps (10 minutes)

Section titled “Get Started in 3 Steps (10 minutes)”

Step 1: Run the wizard once
In the Claude Code interactive REPL, execute:

Describe your preferences, for example: “concise, only necessary explanations, show file diffs by default, friendlier tone.” When finished, the Agent will confirm creation and usage.

Step 2: Persist the result in your project

  • Use Styles as the global/project default writing style; perfect for a “single team voice.”
  • Use custom slash Agents (e.g., @style-concise, @style-reviewer) as toggles to “switch gears anytime.” Agents are just Markdown files — commit to Git and share across the team.

Step 3: Combine with other settings

  • When needed, use /model to switch the model, /status to check status, and the standard /config entrypoint.

3 Practical Examples: Smoother Everyday Dev

Section titled “3 Practical Examples: Smoother Everyday Dev”

1) Small bugfixes: diff by default

  • Directive: @style concise → “say what changed + why + diff.”
  • Value: less scrolling, so you can quickly confirm whether the change is acceptable.
  • Basis: Styles support “more concise, on‑point” output; Claude Code supports turning workflows into custom Agents.

2) Code review: structured feedback

  • Directive: @style reviewer.
  • Output: issue list, risks, suggestions, reusable snippets.
  • Value: turns “vibes and rants” into an “actionable checklist,” better for PR communication.
  • Basis: Styles define tone and structure; Claude Code best practices encourage reusable flows.

3) Onboarding: educational mode

  • Directive: @style educational.
  • Output: step‑by‑step explanations, conceptual threads, comparisons, and small exercises.
  • Value: gets newcomers up to speed without slowing down seniors.
  • Basis: Official Styles include “detailed/explanatory” presets; media reviews also highlight value for learning.

Tips

Section titled “Tips”
  • Bake styles into templates: place a set in /.claude/agents/*.md at the repo root so the team can call them uniformly.
  • Switch by scenario: “Formal” for documentation, “Concise” for debugging, “Reviewer” for refactors.
  • Don’t forget to revert: if a scenario conflicts, switch back to the default Style; Claude follows the principle that style must not affect correctness.

Risks & Limits

Section titled “Risks & Limits”
  • Undocumented features can change: upgrades may rename or move the entry; persist the end result into Styles and slash Agents to avoid surprises.
  • Don’t over‑compress: even when concise, ensure “complete and correct” — the baseline of Claude’s style system.
  • Make it visible for teams: check in style files so PRs/reviews can see and adjust them.

Final Thoughts

Section titled “Final Thoughts”

We used to rely on informal agreements for output style; now it’s one‑click to shape + one‑click to switch.
Wire this into your daily workflow and you’ll find: smoother communication, steadier cadence, and outputs that sound like you.

Which default style would you choose, and why? Share your thoughts.

item.title: Conductor Orchestrates Multiple Claude Code Agents
item.content:encoded:
Conductor: Orchestrate Multiple Claude Code Agents Together

Section titled “Conductor: Orchestrate Multiple Claude Code Agents Together”

In one sentence: Conductor lets you spin up multiple “Claude teammates” at once, each with its own isolated git worktree, so different tasks progress in parallel; you can also see who’s working, who’s stuck, and what changed — all at a glance.

—

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

For complex projects, parallel progress is the productivity unlock. The traditional approach means opening lots of terminals, manually splitting branches, hopping directories — and it’s easy to step on each other’s toes. Conductor turns that workflow into a visual control panel: with a few clicks, you can have multiple Claude Code instances working in their own isolated workspaces simultaneously. It also supports local/GitHub/any Git URL repositories, multi‑tab terminals, Slash commands, message queues, and archiving scripts — the practical stuff you actually need.

❗️Note: This article’s Conductor refers to the macOS app from conductor.build, not the Netflix/Orkes microservices workflow engine “Conductor OSS.” Don’t mix them up.

Highlights & Capabilities

Section titled “Highlights & Capabilities”

1) Visual multi‑agent parallelism: see who’s running, who’s blocked, and what changed

Section titled “1) Visual multi‑agent parallelism: see who’s running, who’s blocked, and what changed”

Each Claude Code instance works independently, while the UI shows status and diffs — a team‑like collaboration experience.

2) Real isolation: each workspace is a new git worktree

Section titled “2) Real isolation: each workspace is a new git worktree”

Not just a temp folder — it’s one worktree + branch per agent, preventing overwrites and conflicts. The official FAQ is explicit: “Yes, each workspace is a new git worktree.”

3) Works with local repos, GitHub, any Git URL

Section titled “3) Works with local repos, GitHub, any Git URL”

Recent changes added local repository support; you can also one‑click clone remote repos and work entirely on your Mac.

4) Built‑in terminal with multiple tabs

Section titled “4) Built‑in terminal with multiple tabs”

Changelog entries repeatedly mention fixes/improvements for terminal tabs, confirming multi‑tab terminal support is built in.

5) Slash commands built in: capture frequent actions into short commands

Section titled “5) Slash commands built in: capture frequent actions into short commands”

The official updates announce Slash commands are live, manageable in settings; they pair nicely with Claude Code’s own Slash mechanism.

6) Message queue and archiving scripts

Section titled “6) Message queue and archiving scripts”

The changelog mentions a message queue (process multiple messages in order) and optional archiving scripts, making it easy to turn conversations and outputs into a traceable asset.

7) Reuse your existing Claude login/keys

Section titled “7) Reuse your existing Claude login/keys”

Conductor directly uses your current Claude Code setup (API key, Pro or Max plan). No redundant configuration.

Installation & Preparation

Section titled “Installation & Preparation”

Platform: currently a macOS app; visit the website and click Download Conductor.

Prep Claude Code: install and ensure Claude Code CLI/native binary works locally (see the official installation script/docs).

First run:

  1. Open Conductor and add a repository as prompted (local path / GitHub / any Git URL).
  2. Choose the number of Claude Code agents to start and give each a task description.
  3. The app will create an independent worktree + branch for each agent and begin execution.

Getting Started: 3 Parallel Scenarios for Everyday Development

Section titled “Getting Started: 3 Parallel Scenarios for Everyday Development”

Scenario A: Fix tests while running Lint and formatting

Section titled “Scenario A: Fix tests while running Lint and formatting”
  • Agent A: fix failing unit tests and assertions
  • Agent B: run ruff/black/eslint/prettier, etc.
  • Agent C: update CI configuration in sync Each agent works on a separate worktree branch without interference; merge them one by one afterward.

Scenario B: Safe rollout + canary/rollback choreography

Section titled “Scenario B: Safe rollout + canary/rollback choreography”
  • Agent A: refactor authentication logic
  • Agent B: write rollback scripts and feature flags
  • Agent C: add SLO monitoring and alerts Turn these into Slash commands like /ship feature-x, /prepare rollback so one tap runs the whole flow.

Scenario C: Documentation and knowledge capture

Section titled “Scenario C: Documentation and knowledge capture”
  • A message queue lets you “throw tasks in to be processed in order,” then batch‑review the results
  • Use archiving scripts to package key conversations, change logs, and outputs (e.g., pre‑release dossiers) (Both features are noted in the official changelog; combine with your team’s conventions for automation.)

Workflow Suggestions (Aligned with Claude Code Best Practices)

Section titled “Workflow Suggestions (Aligned with Claude Code Best Practices)”
  • Crisp task splitting: each agent focuses on one goal (e.g., Auth refactor / new reports page / DSL parser)
  • Maintain isolation: use separate worktree branches for different tasks to avoid blocking and improve merge quality/speed.
  • Template commands: collapse common prompts into Slash commands, turning “boilerplate chatter” into “one‑line instructions.”

Quickstart Checklist

Section titled “Quickstart Checklist”
  1. Install Claude Code (if you haven’t).
  2. Download and open Conductor.
  3. In Conductor, add a repository (local / GitHub / Git URL).
  4. Create multiple agents and write their individual tasks.
  5. Watch logs/commands in the multi‑tab terminal; use the message queue when needed to send batched messages in order.
  6. Use Slash commands to reuse your favorite workflows.
  7. When done, use archiving scripts to package artifacts, or merge branches and ship.

Gotchas & Comparisons

Section titled “Gotchas & Comparisons”
  • Don’t confuse it with Conductor OSS: that’s a microservices orchestration platform (Netflix/Orkes community) — different from this Claude Code GUI.
  • Claude Code only (for now): the FAQ says, “Right now, just Claude Code. Others coming soon.” Don’t expect other models immediately.
  • Performance: parallelism consumes local resources; control agent count and use the message queue to pace execution.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Conductor = multi‑agent parallelism + worktree isolation + visual control. If you constantly juggle multiple tasks and worry about stepping on changes, this tool can instantly boost throughput and flow. Paired with Slash commands and archiving scripts, it turns “manual processes” into standardized buttons and converts “dialogue outputs” into a traceable knowledge base.

Do you think this “multi‑agent in parallel” approach fits your projects? How would you split tasks? Share your experience in the comments.

item.title: Omnara Pushes Real-Time Claude Code / Cursor / Copilot Coding Progress to Your Phone
item.content:encoded:
Omnara Pushes Real-Time Claude Code / Cursor / Copilot Coding Progress to Your Phone

Section titled “Omnara Pushes Real-Time Claude Code / Cursor / Copilot Coding Progress to Your Phone”

Do long-running tasks stall with errors the moment you step away? Omnara, an open-source project, makes “human-in-the-loop” the default: monitor every step in real time, push critical checkpoints to your phone, and let you chime in with guidance anytime. No more discovering hours later that an agent crashed long ago.

The project site, docs, installation flow, and iOS client are live — you can try it now.

Why Use Omnara?

Section titled “Why Use Omnara?”

It tackles real pain points:

  • Real-time visibility: a timeline shows each agent action and its context. You’ll instantly see where it’s stuck.
  • Two-way human–agent dialogue: when uncertain, the agent pauses proactively, sends a notification to your phone, and waits for your brief instruction to proceed.
  • Mobile-first: iOS client plus web console — review and approve even on the subway.
  • Unified command center: manage Claude Code, Cursor, GitHub Copilot, and more in one panel.
  • Two operating modes:
    1. Monitor local sessions in real time;
    2. Initiate remotely — trigger tasks from your phone to run on your machine.
  • Protocol-friendly: supports MCP (Model Context Protocol), plus REST/Python SDKs for easy extension.
  • Open source + pricing: code is Apache-2.0; official Free/Pro ($9/mo) service and iOS IAP available.

Latest release v1.4.10 is out, fixing notification and other details.

Three-Minute Setup: Install and Start

Section titled “Three-Minute Setup: Install and Start”

Option A | Monitor local Claude Code sessions (recommended first run)

After launch, your browser opens for login/binding; from then on, every step in your local Claude Code sessions streams live to the dashboard, and critical prompts get pushed to your phone.

Option B | Initiate tasks remotely from your phone

Use the webhook URL printed in the terminal to add an agent in the mobile app. You can then start/pause/resume jobs from your phone.

How It Fits with Popular Tools

Section titled “How It Fits with Popular Tools”

1) Claude Code (terminal / inside editor)

Section titled “1) Claude Code (terminal / inside editor)”
  • Wrap your Claude Code session with omnara as above.

2) Cursor

item.title: Claude Code’s Opus Plan Mode: Cheaper and Smarter
item.content:encoded:
Claude Code’s “Opus Plan Mode” = Plan with Opus, execute with Sonnet. It turns what we’ve been doing manually — “Opus thinks, Sonnet does” — into a one‑click strategy: let the stronger Opus handle complex reasoning, and let the more cost‑effective Sonnet actually write and modify files.

How to Enable

Section titled “How to Enable”
  • In the terminal, type /model and select the Opus Plan Mode option from the menu; use /status anytime to check the current model.
  • Enter/exit Plan Mode: press Shift+Tab (most terminals require two quick presses). In this mode it only analyzes and plans — it won’t edit files or run commands.
  • When you’re ready to actually implement, exit Plan Mode (via shortcut or the ExitPlanMode tool).

Why It Saves Tokens

Section titled “Why It Saves Tokens”
  • Official pricing: Opus 4.1 $15/$75 (input/output per million tokens), Sonnet 4 $3/$15. Opus is roughly 5× more expensive. Use it only for “thinking/planning” and hand code generation to Sonnet — your costs drop accordingly.
  • Additionally, Claude Code has a default hybrid strategy: start with Opus up to a quota, then automatically switch to Sonnet (recommended default). It balances “power vs. cost”.

When to Use It

Section titled “When to Use It”
  • Unfamiliar repo analysis → solution design → task breakdown: In Plan Mode, have Opus summarize the architecture, list change steps and acceptance criteria; once confirmed, execute. Plan Mode itself supports “analyze only, no hands-on changes”.
  • High‑risk changes (upgrades, refactors, migrations): first have Opus write a detailed implementation plan and rollback strategy, then use Sonnet to implement step by step.
  • Long‑running agents: decoupling planning from execution keeps costs controllable and moves closer to agents that can run complex tasks for extended periods.

Tips

Section titled “Tips”
  • Want safer defaults: set permissions.defaultMode to plan so you plan first, execute later.
  • Use /model to switch combinations on the fly (e.g., temporarily use Opus end‑to‑end to get past a roadblock).

Notes

Section titled “Notes”
  • Heavy users may encounter new weekly limits for now (mainly targeting 24/7 “whale‑style” agent usage). During planning, articulate the approach clearly and reuse plans to reduce wasted reasoning.

In short: Opus “thinks it through,” Sonnet “gets it done.” Same progress, lower cost, and the “plan → execute” cadence becomes a baked‑in workflow. Your intuition is spot‑on — this does push agents a step closer to “complex tasks that can run long and steady”.

In one sentence: terminalcp = Playwright for the terminal.
It lets an AI agent start, operate, and read any command‑line tool (LLDB/GDB, Python REPL, database shells, even other AI CLIs) like a human—and lets you and me take over the same session at any time.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

You may already use Playwright/Browser for web automation—so what about an “automation console” for the command line?
terminalcp abstracts “what a human does in the terminal” into an MCP tool: start a process → send keystrokes → read output → manage multiple sessions, and also supports socket attach so you can watch and take over the AI’s actions in real time.

1) Truly interactive control
Not just “run a command and exit,” but persistent sessions: single‑step in LLDB/GDB, try code in a REPL, or view the “full screen” in TUI apps like vim/htop.

2) Two output modes, pick as needed

  • Terminal mode (stdout): captures the rendered screen buffer, perfect for debuggers and TUIs.
  • Stream mode: captures the raw text stream (ANSI stripped by default), and supports incremental reads with since_last—more efficient for builds/logs.

3) High‑fidelity PTY
Processes run in a pseudo‑terminal, preserving colors/cursor moves/special key sequences—just like human input; plus it manages multiple processes in the background so your agent doesn’t block.

4) Socket attach: the key to human–AI collaboration
Each process automatically exposes a Unix domain socket. You can attach to an already‑running AI session to co‑view and co‑operate, jumping in to help anytime.

5) More “AI‑friendly” than screen/tmux

  • Structured responses (JSON) instead of a wall of text.
